segments.text: His youngest child was a little girl who came for a time to live with my father's family.
When she was about 13 and my dad was about 9, she came and she tells the story of the time that the great-grandmother had been left at home with her
as the others went to the cotton fields to pick cotton that she was left at home while she studied because she was in school to look after.
And not being used to doing this, she accidentally let her get away.
She was sitting at the table studying when she noticed the grandmother had gotten a cup of coffee, and the next thing she knew,

She had run out the front door and the front yard gate and down the road and she couldn't but the time she got out of the house she was running out into a wooded area and she lost her in the thick thick wooded part and couldn't find her and she became so upset that she ran to the cotton fields and got the rest of the family and they all came and combed the area all afternoon and that night until
sometime at the night, and couldn't find the grandmother anywhere.
And early the next morning, the nearest neighbor, about a half a mile or three-quarters of a mile up the road,
was leaving to go to the cotton gin with a wagon load of cotton.
He had the cotton sheet already tied down on it, and early the next morning about daylight, he started out to the cotton gin.
And if you've ever been to a cotton gin, the wagons drive up beside a ramp, and there is a sort of a vacuum cleaner suction type,
funnel, which comes down over the cotton in the wagon and sucks it up into the gin.
And as the men took off the cotton sheet that morning, there was Grandmother Kathy lying up in the middle of the bale of cotton, all soft as she'd spent the night and had kept them warm.
Of course, I suppose it was in August, so it was hot anyway, but, uh,
They were all so astonished to find her in the neighborhood of my home that day.
My great-grandmother was quite a character, I understand.
She had lived on a plantation before the Civil War in Alabama and had had several slaves.
And after she became senile and lost complete touch with reality,
My daddy, as a little boy, would just listen to her and the things she'd say, and she'd stand at the window and give directions to her slaves.
Give everybody directions for the day.
And there was one named Caroline, which I suppose was Caroline, and one named Ike, and I don't remember other names, but my dad was so fascinated with how she thought and her
reactions of what she would do, but of course all of this went with the Civil War, and I don't feel that that had an effect on her becoming senile.
It was just that that was her way of life, and she still lived in that way in her thinking when she became older.
Okay.
After you moved to this area and after you got older, do you remember if there were any political bosses in this area?
Or who controlled the use of the land?
Who said, this man can have this area and this man can have this area?
Was there any sort of time of control?
Now, I don't recall, or I was not...
I didn't realize if there was any sort of control in this area.
I can remember as a child, people talking about down in the southern part of the state, there were a lot of

problems then i believe there was a man named parr that had quite a political bill i'm not sure of the word but an empire a political empire in that part of the country and he really did control this is the only
person in this area anywhere near that I can recall.
I believe his name was Parr.
I think it was Duval County.
I see.
What was the size of Bryan College Station when you first remember it?
I came to Bryan College Station in 1951, and it was much smaller then.
I suppose the total population would have been
I think Brown was about 18,000.
And College Station, about 6,000 to 8,000.
Were they connected?
There was a lot of vacant space in between.
I can remember when there were no supermarkets.
on the highway at all, on Highway 6.
And when the first sort of supermarket was built, it was called Miller's, I believe, and it was where, it's right near Sherwin-Williams store there on the corner.
And this was sitting out on the highway out there all by itself.
There was nothing on there.
And I can remember when the first
nice motel was built.
There was some little, small tourist port type, old-fashioned ports, two or three on the highway.
But the Sands Motel was the largest and the biggest and the finest.
It was the very first.
But there was a lot of just...
undeveloped area between Bryan and College Station.
Now at one time, back when the college was just sitting out here by itself, there was an old trolley which ran between the campus and Bryan, an old trolley line.
Who do you think were the most influential families of the area back then?
Well now, some of the first families

to come here i'm not sure if they were the most influential but they were real interested in developing the area my husband's family came in 1921 and at that time there were no houses in this off except in brian there were no houses around the college they had campus housing had

old college houses that were in rows on the campus and all the faculty and administration lived in the campus housing and my husband's father and mother built the first house here on this lot that was ever built off the campus i think in 1922 and this was just a trail uh through this little wooded area down here and
The little park that's Dexter Park now was a lake.
There was a dam across the south end of the park.
It was sort of where the little bridge is now.
And it had been dammed up, and it was...
They enjoyed the lake, but really it was not a real scenic type thing.
It was mosquito-infested.
But...
The first families to build off the campus were on this street.
And my husband's family and five others formed the Southside Development Company.
And they developed this whole area.
I mean, they developed, I suppose, what's called South Park right in here where we live.
It's not a very large area now, but it was the first development off the campus around this little Dexter Park.
What type of social services were there then, like fire police, schools, telephone?
Is it pretty much like it is now, or has it changed a lot?
In 1951, there was only one school out at
College Station.
It's in the local here on Jersey Street.
The grade school was there, the junior high and the high school.
They were in different buildings.
The school system was not very wealthy.

There's not much to tax in this area except just local families, and it was a rather poor school district as far as financing, but an excellent school system in that it had such good teachers and could draw from resources at the college.
But the grade school was housed in little wooden buildings, which people jokingly called the chicken coops.
They weren't very attractive.
They're still there, but used just for storage and other things now.
But this was the one school out here.
And at that time, it was much smaller.
It may have been a B school or an A school.
Now it's AAA.
It was a very small school.
As a Girl Scout worker, I worked with all the schools in the area.
The College Station school consolidated.
It was a very outstanding school.
One of the best, the elementary school was recognized as one of the top ten in the nation at that time for its reading program and other areas.
It was far advanced, its reading techniques and that sort of thing.
The Bryan schools were very good schools too, but as far as police and
I think it was very adequate in the fire, that sort of thing.
But, of course, it's had to grow with the community because it's so much larger now.
Awesome.
Well, I think that about concludes the interview.
I want to thank you very much for this.
Well, thank you for asking.
I really enjoyed it.
I did, too.
Thank you for asking.
